item.title: CBR Labs: Frozen Beer Glass Experiment
item.description:
The first CBR Labs Experiment. What is the effect of a frozen beer glass on the temperature of the beer over time?


The Frozen Glass Experiment

from the Craft Beer Radio Research Laboratory

Problem: How much effect does chilled and frozen beer glasses have on the overall temperature of the beer that is served in the glass

Hypothesis: The thermal mass of a refrigerated or frozen standard shaker pint will continue to chill the liquid added to the glass for a period of time that will significantly effect the beer drinking experience.

Glass under test: Libbey Glass 5139 16oz. Mixing Glass 5 ⅞ inches tall, 3 ½ inches wide at the top, 2 ⅜ inches wide at the base weighing 413 grams. http://foodservice.libbey.com/catalogs/foodservice-glassware/2012-Glassware-Foodservice.pdf Page 81.

Preliminary Research: A Twitter inquiry asking bar employees what their draft cooler temperatures were set to resulted in a range from 36 - 42 degrees Fahrenheit.  This will be used to prepare the beer analogue to a proper temperature to experiment with.

Experiment:

  1. Prepare 3 test glasses at the following temperatures.  The glasses were stored in the appropriate environment for 2.5 hours prior to experiment.
  1. 65F, a room temperature control.
  2. 37F, kitchen refrigerator temperature
  3. -3F, freezer temperature
  1. Prepare 48oz. of water at 39.2F to use as the beer analogue.
  2. Add an equal amount of water to each glass.  
  3. Measure and collect the temperature of the water every 2 minutes for the first 20 and every 5 minutes thereafter up to 1 hour.

Results: 

The results from the experiment show that the frozen glass on average was 7.2F lower than the liquid in the room temperature control.  The maximum difference peaked at 8.6 degrees as the frozen glass and the liquid reached equilibrium.  

A plot of temperature differences over time reveals that the effect of the frozen glass persists throughout the length of the experiment. It is still 70% of the maximum  difference at 60 minutes when the experiment ended.  

It’s worth noting an unofficial data point, after 2 hours the difference was still around 4 degrees. This is still half of the maximum difference measured.

The difference in temperature over time does not show how it effects the drinking experience. However if you look at times it takes to reach equal temperatures it becomes much more apparent.   It took the frozen glass 20 minutes to warm back to initial serving temperature and 35 minutes to match the temperature of the control glass after only 1 minute.  Below is a table describing the amount of time for the beers to achieve the same temperature.

Temperature

Control Glass

Refrigerated Glass

Frozen Glass

41F

1 minute

4 minutes

29 minutes

45F

10 minutes

23 minutes

45 minutes

50F

37 minutes

55 minutes

N/A*

* The experiment ended before the frozen glass reached 50F.

Finally the raw data plot.  Here you can see the chilling effect of the frozen glass during the first 20 minutes and how the frozen glass fails to make.  One additional thing to note on the graph would be that room temperature was 65F.

Conclusion: The results of the experiment confirmed my hypothesis and expectations.  That a frozen glass has a significant effect on the beer drinking experience.  I had the expectation from personal experience that the frozen glass would take approximately 15 minutes to warm up to drinking temperature.  Where in this experiment an un-handled glass actually takes 20 minutes to return to the temperature that beer was poured at and 35 minutes to even start to get to a desired drinking temperature which exceeded my expectations.

Followup Considerations: There are several variables that could be explored in followup experiments that may effect the results.

  1. Is plain tap water an appropriate analogue for beer?
  2. What is the effect of removing the liquid from the glasses to simulate a standard drinking session.
  3. What is the effect of handling the glass as it would typically be during a drinking session.
  4. What is the effect of agitating the liquid vs leaving it settled.
item.dc:creator: jbearer

item.title: CBR 186: Sam Adams Latitude 48 Deconstructed
